block.p: A Mercedes to the Rescue SATURDAY -- The Bruce Museum of Arts and Science in Greenwich, Conn., will raise money for its educational programs and exhibitions at a dinner-dance. The black-tie evening, at the Bydale Estate in Greenwich, will start with drinks and a silent auction at 6:30. Dinner is at 8:30, with a live auction at 9 that will include a new Mercedes-Benz E320. Music by the Starlight Express Orchestra. Tickets, $350, from (203) 869-6786, ext. 328.

A Mercedes to the Rescue SATURDAY -- The Bruce Museum of Arts and Science in Greenwich, Conn., will raise money for its educational programs and exhibitions at a dinner-dance. The black-tie evening, at the Bydale Estate in Greenwich, will start with drinks and a silent auction at 6:30. Dinner is at 8:30, with a live auction at 9 that will include a new Mercedes-Benz E320. Music by the Starlight Express Orchestra. Tickets, $350, from (203) 869-6786, ext. 328.

Footlights and Toeholds JUNE 5 -- Inside Broadway will benefit from a revue it is staging about the music and lyrics of Rodgers and Hammerstein, called ''All Kinds of People.'' Kristin Chenoweth, the actress, will be among those receiving Broadway Beacon Awards. The organization produces shows in the city's schools and provides tickets for schoolchildren to Broadway theater events. The evening begins at 6 with drinks and hors d'oeuvres at Loews New York Hotel, with the show to follow at 7. Tickets, $150, from (212) 398-6740.

Learning Through Art JUNE 5 -- The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum will hold a gala to benefit Learning Through Art, its classroom arts education program for children in New York City; Trenton; Bilbao, Spain; Mexico City; and other locations around the world. The event begins at 6:30 with a cocktail reception and a viewing of artwork by children who are participants in the program. Dinner will follow at 8. Wynton Marsalis will be the evening's host, and there will be a silent auction that includes a trip for two to Venice, featuring first-class airfare and stays at both the Cipriani and the Bauer hotels. Black tie. Tickets, $500, or $150 for the reception alone, from (212) 423-3670.

A Dinner for the Ages JUNE 5 -- The American Jewish Historical Society will honor Sanford I. Weill at a dinner to raise money to support and expand the organization's archives. The black-tie evening, at the Plaza, begins with cocktails at 6:30; dinner will follow at 7:30. Tickets, $600, from (212) 245-6570.

Hemisphere to Hemisphere JUNE 6 -- The Americas Society will raise money at a dinner at Tavern on the Green for its educational programs that promote understanding of the peoples and nations in North and South America. The black-tie evening begins at 7:30 with drinks; dinner is at 8:30. Tickets, $750, from (212) 249-8950.

'Renewal' at the Boathouse JUNE 6 -- An auction and cocktail party at the Central Park Boathouse will raise money for Project Renewal's outreach, treatment, housing and employment programs for mentally ill and drug-addicted homeless people. The evening begins at 6 with drinks and hors d'oeuvres, with the auction at 7. Tickets, $150, from (212) 620-0340.

Wave Hill Gala JUNE 6 -- Flowers on the blooming landscapes of Wave Hill will be a centerpiece of a benefit for the organization's programs in horticulture, environmental education, land management and other areas. The gala begins at 7 with drinks. Dinner is at 8:30, with dancing to the music of Peter Duchin and his orchestra. Tickets, $500, from (718) 549-3200, ext. 260.

Remembering the Old Days JUNE 7 -- Malachy McCourt, portraying an old-fashioned Tammany Hall politician, will be among those entertaining at a dinner to raise money for the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, which is developing an exhibition on the Irish immigrant experience in America. The evening will take place at the New York Athletic Club, 180 Central Park South (Seventh Avenue). Drinks at 6 and dinner at 7:30. Tickets, $350, from (212) 431-0233, ext. 218.

For Language Skills JUNE 7 -- Former Governor Mario M. Cuomo will speak at a benefit dinner at the Starlight Roof at the Waldorf-Astoria for the International Center. The organization provides English-language training and programs in American culture for foreign-born newcomers. The black-tie evening begins at 6:30 with drinks, with dinner at 7:30 and the speech. Tickets, $350, from (212) 355-6363.

Youth Programs at the Y JUNE 7 -- The youth scholarship fund of the Y.M.C.A. of Greater New York will benefit from a dinner-dance in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The black-tie evening begins with cocktails at 6, with dinner to follow at 7. Danny Glover will be the master of ceremonies. Dancing to the music of Peter Duchin and his orchestra. Tickets, $750, from (212) 630-9625.

Let the Music Begin JUNE 7 -- Kid Rock, the musician, and members of the Blue Man Group will perform at a dinner at Tavern on the Green to benefit the social service programs of the UJA-Federation of New York. The organization will honor Jason Flom, the president of Lava Records. Cocktails are at 6:30 and dinner at 7:30, with the performances to follow. Tickets, $500, from (212) 836-1126.

For Alzheimer's JUNE 7 -- Members of the Big Apple Circus will perform at a black-tie dinner at the American Museum of Natural History to raise money for the New York chapter of the Alzheimer's Association. Herman Badillo will be among those honored. Drinks at 6:30 will be followed by dinner at 7:30 and the show. Tickets, $500, from (212) 665-9177.

Party With the Gorillas JUNE 8 -- The Wildlife Conservation Society will hold its annual gala at the Bronx Zoo, raising money for New York City's zoos and aquarium. The evening begins with drinks at 5:30 in the Congo Gorilla Forest exhibit, with dinner and dancing to follow under a tent in the Wild Asia area at 8. Music by Bob Hardwick Sound. Jack and Lewis Rudin will be honored, as will William G. Conway, a senior conservationist and the society's former president and general director. Tickets, $600, from (718) 220-5090.

Art for Art's Sake JUNE 8 -- Works of art by Christo, David Bowie, Todd Oldham, Kiki Smith, Jock Sturges and others will be auctioned at a benefit for the scholarships and programs of the New York Academy of Art, 111 Franklin Street (West Broadway). The evening begins at 7 with drinks and hors d'oeuvres. The works can be previewed June 2 through June 7. Tickets, $175, from (212) 966-0300, or $200 at the door.

Safe Havens JUNE 8 -- Sophie B. Hawkins, a pop singer, will perform at a benefit at the Metropolitan Pavilion, 125 West 18th Street, for Sanctuary for Families. The organization provides services for victims of domestic violence, including emergency shelter and legal representation. A cocktail reception at 7 will be followed by dinner at 8. Tickets, $500, or $100 for the performance alone, beginning at 8:30, from (212) 349-6009, ext. 241.

A Whirl Around the Park JUNE 8 -- The Central Park Conservancy will celebrate spring with a dinner and dance at Bethesda Terrace in Central Park. Drinks and a silent auction at 7:30 will be followed by dinner at 8:30, with dishes prepared by a number of New York chefs. Tickets, $200, from (212) 310-6616.

Muscle on Madison Square JUNE 11 -- The City Parks Foundation will begin a series of one-hour Sunday ''boot camp'' exercise classes in Madison Square Park (weather permitting). Each will be followed by a brunch at the Madison Square Club, 210 Fifth Avenue (26th Street). The classes, which begin at 9:30 a.m., will raise money for the renovation of Madison Square Park. Additional classes and brunches will be held on June 18 and 25, and July 9 and 16. Tickets, $100, for one class, or $500 for the entire series, (212) 683-1836.

A 42nd Street Debut JUNE 12 -- Ann Reinking will direct a staged reading of Noel Coward's ''Red Peppers'' at the New 42nd Street Studios, a complex of 14 rehearsal studios at 229 West 42nd Street. Charlotte d'Amboise, Bill Irwin and Terrence Mann will be among those participating, and Julie Kent and Jose Manuel Carreno from the American Ballet Theater will perform ''Other Dances'' by Jerome Robbins. The event, which starts with cocktails at 6:30, marks the opening of a new 199-seat theater, the Duke on 42nd Street, and the dedication of a new rehearsal space called the Jerome Robbins Studio, both located in the New 42nd Street Studios. Dinner will be served at 8:30. Proceeds go to the New 42nd Street Inc., a nonprofit group that is renovating seven historic theaters on the street. Tickets, $1,000, from (212) 564-4222, ext. 225.

Amfar Dance Party JUNE 12 -- A dance party at the Boathouse Cafe in Central Park will raise money for the research, prevention and advocacy programs supported by the American Foundation for AIDS Research. A silent auction will include a six-day trip for two to Negril, Jamaica, and there will be an auction of framed, signed kisses from celebrities who include Madonna, Bill Cosby, Rosie O'Donnell, Barbara Walters, Bob Hope and Susan Sarandon. Tickets, $125, from (212) 806-1757.

Carnival in Lincoln Center JUNE 12 -- A party on the promenade of the New York State Theater will take its theme from the annual carnival in Rio de Janeiro. Guests and members of the New York City Ballet will dance and dine together. The evening, a fund-raiser for the company, begins with drinks at 8. A buffet will be served throughout the event. Black tie or carnival dress. Tickets, $175, from (212) 870-5585.

Actors' Fund Performances JUNE 12 -- Christopher Reeve and Bran Pace, a dancer who was left paralyzed after a mugging, will be honored at a benefit for both the Actors' Fund of America and for the Christopher Reeve Paralysis Foundation. The evening will feature performances by Blythe Danner, Rosemary Harris, Nathan Lane and others at the New Amsterdam Theater, 214 West 42nd Street (Broadway). The event is to begin at 7:30, with a party with the cast to follow. Tickets, $1,000, or $50 and up for the performance alone, from (212) 221-7300, ext. 121.

Rockefeller Center Dining JUNE 12 -- American and French chefs will turn their talents to barbecue at a benefit for Citymeals-on-Wheels, which delivers prepared meals to the elderly throughout New York City. The black-tie and blue jeans event begins at 7:30, and will take place on the esplanade of Rockefeller Center and at some of the restaurants around it. Guests will dance to the music of the Blues Jumpers. Tickets, $375, from (212) 687-1290.

Songs for AIDS JUNE 12 -- Audra McDonald will perform at a concert benefit for Gay Men's Health Crisis, the New York AIDS service organization. The evening at Town Hall will begin at 8, with a cocktail reception at the Hudson Theater, 145 West 44th Street (Broadway), immediately following the concert. Tickets, $250, from (212) 367-1514, or $35 and up for the concert alone, from (212) 307-4100.

American Art Award JUNE 12 -- The Whitney Museum will hold its annual American Art Award dinner at the museum, Madison Avenue at 75th Street. Proceeds from the event go to support exhibitions, education and public programs. Cocktails at 7 will be followed by dinner and the presentation of the award to the Chase Manhattan Corporation. Black tie. Tickets, $1,500, from (212) 570-7775.

For Youth Leadership JUNE 13 -- Outward Bound, the youth leadership organization, will raise money for its programs for New York City public school children at a dinner and dance to be held under the Tent at Lincoln Center, which is on the Fordham University campus (62nd Street at Amsterdam Avenue). Dr. Richard C. Levin, the president of Yale University, will be among those honored. The evening begins at 6:30 with drinks. Dinner and dancing will start at 7:30. Tickets, $500, from (212) 972-2268.

Metropolitan Opera Auction JUNE 14 -- An auction at Christie's of opera memorabilia, luxury goods and services, travel packages and other items will raise money for an educational program that brings students to performances of the Metropolitan Opera each year. The evening begins at 6 with a Champagne reception and a silent auction. At 8 is a live auction. Tickets, $75, or $60 for those under 30, from (212) 769-7068.

For Mental Health Care JUNE 15 -- A cocktail party at the Pfizer Building, 150 East 42nd Street (Lexington Avenue), will raise money for the advocacy work of the Coalition of Voluntary Mental Health Agencies. The event begins at 5 with drinks and hors d'oeuvres. Tickets, $125, from (212) 586-4555, ext. 18.

Art Conservation JUNE 21 -- Sculpture by David Smith on the Metropolitan Museum of Art's roof garden will be on view at a benefit for art conservation at the Met. The evening, organized by the Met's younger supporters, begins at 6:30 with cocktails and hors d'oeuvres. Tickets, $125, from (212) 570-3948, or $140 at the door.

Songs for a Cause JUNE 26 -- Donna Summer will perform at a benefit for the New York Hospital Medical Center of Queens, to take place at the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center. The black-tie evening begins with cocktails at 6:30, with dinner at 7:30. The performance is at 9:30, followed by Champagne and dessert. Tickets, $500, from (718) 670-1009.
